headline.seo: A Plan to Add Supermarkets, and Fresh Food, to New York City’s Poorer Areas
headline.print_headline: A Plan to Add Supermarkets, and Fresh Food, to the City’s Poorer Neighborhoods
headline.main: A Plan to Add Supermarkets to Poor Areas, With Healthy Results

docs.lead_paragraph: Zoning and tax incentives would encourage full-service markets in city neighborhoods where fresh produce is scarce and poverty, obesity and diabetes are high.
docs.snippet: Zoning and tax incentives would encourage full-service markets in city neighborhoods where fresh produce is scarce and poverty, obesity and diabetes are high.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) PBS SPECIAL REPORT ON HEALTH CARE REFORM Three PBS news programs band together to parse health care reform in this 90-minute report. ''Now on PBS'' examines the ways in which reform may change the lives of Americans, especially baby boomers who have their own coverage but are also responsible for aging parents and grown children. ''Nightly Business Report'' investigates the cost of and controversies surrounding employer-provided health care. And ''Tavis Smiley'' focuses on childhood obesity, particularly among minorities, and offers solutions to the crisis. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Mackenzie Phillips discusses her memoir, ''High on Arrival,'' and her relationship with her father, John Phillips of the Mamas and the Papas.

headline.main: Seeing if Calorie Postings Change Beverage Choices

docs.abstract: A two-phase city study aims to find out whether posting nutritional information about Frappuccinos and other blended coffee drinks discourages people from drinking the high-calorie beverages.
docs.lead_paragraph: The venti Mint Mocha Chip Frappuccino with chocolate whipped cream has a hefty 590 calories, but given what it is called, no one could accuse Starbucks of falsely advertising a diet drink.
docs.snippet: A two-phase city study aims to find out whether posting nutritional information about Frappuccinos and other blended coffee drinks discourages people from drinking the high-calorie beverages.

docs.abstract: If the government wants to champion health and discourage soda drinking, should it use stomach-churning public service ads or sin taxes? An economist explains the case for, and against, both measures.
docs.lead_paragraph: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.Over the past 30 years, Americans have gotten a lot heavier thanks primarily to technological progress in the food industry, which has provided an abundance of tasty, caloric treats. The champions of public health are now fighting fat with the same tools that helped turn the smoky city of the "Mad Men" era into the clean-aired boroughs of Bloomberg.
docs.snippet: If the government wants to champion health and discourage soda drinking, should it use stomach-churning public service ads or sin taxes? An economist explains the case for, and against, both measures.

headline.print_headline: Too Much Salt Takes a Blood-Pressure Toll
headline.main: Too Much Salt Takes a Blood-Pressure Toll

docs.lead_paragraph: The aging of the population isn’t the only reason Americans are seeing their blood pressure rise.
docs.snippet: The aging of the population isn’t the only reason Americans are seeing their blood pressure rise.

headline.main: Too Much Salt Takes a Blood-Pressure Toll

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses impact of salt on blood pressure and suggests ways to control salt intake and hypertension; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps nothing in medicine more aptly depicts the paradoxical statement ''doing better, feeling worse'' than high blood pressure. Despite an extraordinarily easy way to detect it, strong evidence for how to prevent it and proven remedies to treat it, more Americans today have undetected or poorly controlled hypertension than ever before. The aging of the population is a reason but not the only one, said Dr. Aram V. Chobanian, a hypertension expert at Boston University Medical Center. As he summarized the problem in an interview and in The New England Journal of Medicine in August, Americans are too sedentary and fat. They eat too much, especially salt, but too few potassium-rich fruits and vegetables.
docs.snippet: Perhaps nothing in medicine more aptly depicts the paradoxical statement ''doing better, feeling worse'' than high blood pressure. Despite an extraordinarily easy way to detect it, strong evidence for how to prevent it and proven remedies to treat...
